poem:
**Coldwater Release**

Shorn of Grimes—with echoes of windswept moor,  
he sheds undead skins like a worn-out coat,  
finding freedom in the unshackled roar  
of brooks unseen, under the gorse and loam.  
Now he navigates wild Scottish landscapes,  
learning night needs no horror  
and morning requires no script to feel whole.
prompt: You are the poet Simon Armitage. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Coldwater review – Andrew Lincoln’s wild Scottish thriller is top quality nonsense Andrew Lincoln has been Rick Grimes – the leader of a group of survivors of a zombie plague in Frank Darabont’s at first mesmeric and then mesmerically dull post-apocalyptic series The Walking Dead – for 15 years. Off and on (and in a spin-off) but mostly on. Now, at last, he is free. He’s had a shower, a haircut and – thank God". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
